It might be normal to imagine that a good
society would be one in which a majority of

5.text:
people held optimistic views about themselves,
their fellow citizens and their prospects

11.text:
for their collective futures. But, in fact,
quite the opposite appears to be true: deep

17.text:
pessimism seems a key ingredient for the maintenance
of any good society. At the core of pessimism

23.text:
is the idea that everyone, however outwardly
normal, is severely flawed: short-term, blinkered,

30.text:
vengeful, sentimental and prone to reckless
anger, fear, delusion and passion. We’re

36.text:
mad monkeys, with a few extra neurones. From
a brutal acceptance of this dark starting-point,

42.text:
there can flow a range of measures that together
will make for exceptionally wise, calm and

49.text:
reasonable societies. Let’s consider a few:
In an ideally pessimistic society, rather

55.text:
boring and extremely steady politicians are
the norm. No one believes the wilder utopian

61.text:
promises of firebrand leaders. The electorate
is simply far too pessimistic to trust in

67.text:
easy, rapid solutions to any of the nation’s
substantial problems. Dramatic promises at

73.text:
the stump are immediately discounted with
a wry, dismissive shrug. Because pessimists

79.text:
know just how flawed any one individual can
be, the ideal pessimistic society invests

85.text:
heavily in strong, slow-moving, independent
institutions that prevent too much power from

91.text:
ever falling into the hands of a single person.
Furthermore, these institutions are insulated

96.text:
from the fluctuations of public opinion – which,
pessimistically, are seen as being hugely

102.text:
prone to hysteria and overreaction. In the
ideal pessimistic society, there won’t be

108.text:
much appetite for singling out any particular
group or class of people for blame. Our troubles,

114.text:
the electorate sadly admit, are caused mainly
by big impersonal, historical forces – rather

121.text:
than by a few people who are easy to target
and cathartically hate. Because they assume

127.text:
that it’s natural to have rather dangerous
appetites and desires, the citizens of a pessimistic

132.text:
society willingly put quite a lot of restraints
on themselves, defining freedom not as the

138.text:
ability to do whatever they want at any point,
but as the liberty to act in accordance with

144.text:
their wisest, most reasonable selves (which
only appear every now and then). They therefore

150.text:
don’t see it as any particular loss of freedom
to be gently nudged away from blowing their

155.text:
savings, overeating, doing no exercise, ruining
their relationships or developing addictions.

161.text:
They accept a paternalistic society as the
natural price for limiting their own self-destructive

168.text:
tendencies. Pessimistic societies don’t
have much time for celebrity culture, for

174.text:
they are dubious about whether anyone much
deserves to be idolised: they know that from

179.text:
close up, we’re all a bit of a mess. And
they’re not shocked by revelations of chaotic

184.text:
private lives, since this is assumed to be
the norm. Spare energy is directed more towards

190.text:
forgiveness rather than adulation followed
by denigration. In pessimistic societies,

196.text:
the education system is elaborate, broad,
ambitious and very well resourced; citizens

202.text:
assume that the raw human mind needs a huge
amount of structured, targeted help in order

208.text:
to cope with life’s challenges. The curriculum
isn’t merely focused on technical skills

213.text:
though; there is a lot of help around emotional
issues too – which, it’s acknowledged,

218.text:
are at the root of so many of our tragedies.
Because they acknowledge that we’re all

223.text:
fragile, easily irked creatures, pessimistic
societies place great emphasis on creating

228.text:
quietly uplifting and beautiful communal environments.
Cities are marked by elegance, simplicity,

235.text:
rationality and harmony. A stridently ugly
tower block, a depressingly chaotic airport,

241.text:
a squalid railway station – they darkly
admit – could be enough to drive someone

246.text:
to despair. The rich have always recognized
this for themselves; a pessimistic society

251.text:
merely differs in regarding this as a universal
truth. In optimistic societies, there are

257.text:
constant claims that everyone can be exceptional
and, one day, awe-inspiringly successful.

264.text:
The charms and rewards of life are therefore
fundamentally geared towards those who make

268.text:
it to the top. The best restaurants are superb,
the private hospitals are outstanding, the

274.text:
most expensive schools magnificent, the richest
residential areas delightful, the taxes for

280.text:
the rich very low. But, naively, such societies
forget that, by statistical inevitability,

287.text:
most people are actually not going to be successful
at all. So in the pessimistic society, mediocrity

294.text:
and relative failure are assumed to be the
norm and the goal of government is understood

299.text:
to be that of rendering an average life (that
is, the life most people will actually lead)

305.text:
as attractive as possible. Public housing,
state schools, public hospitals and transportation

311.text:
are all superb, because it’s assumed (with
extreme realism) that we’re almost all going

317.text:
to be relying on them. By following such pessimistic
dictates, the profound consequence will be

324.text:
a society where – paradoxically – there
will be rather a lot to be cheerful about

329.text:
– though, of course, the wary, gloomy and
wise citizenry would never quite dare to put
